At that time, Maitreya Bodhisattva heard the Buddha's words, rose from his seat, and said to the Buddha:

Not far to the south of where Bodhisattva Shakyamuni received his prediction, there are the remaining traces of walking meditation by the four Buddhas of the past, over fifty steps long and about seven feet high, built with blue stone, with an image of the Tathagata walking on top. Each told the story, and they arranged the order of seniority. The transformation gradually reached far and near, and people knew the hierarchy. Monks and laypeople took refuge.
Not far to the side, in a large forest, there is a stupa where the Tathagata, when practicing the bodhisattva path, together with Devadatta, acted as the king of deer to settle a matter.
In the past, in this large forest, there were two herds of deer, each with over five hundred members.
At that time, the king of this country went hunting in the marshes. The bodhisattva deer king came forward and said to the king:
Great king, you are hunting in the marshes, setting fires and shooting arrows. All of us will die this morning, and in a few days we will be rotten and useless for food.
We wish to take turns, sending one deer a day.
The king has the delicacies of fresh meat, and I extend the life of a few days and nights.
The king approved of his words, turned the carriage around, and returned.
The two groups of deer took turns sending their lives.
In the Ti-po group, there was a pregnant deer whose turn it was to die. She said to her king:
Although my body should die, my child has not yet had its turn.
The deer king angrily said:
Who does not treasure their life!
The doe sighed and said:
Our king is not benevolent, and death will come soon.
She then urgently appealed to the Bodhisattva deer king.
The deer king said:
Alas! The heart of a compassionate mother extends to her unborn child.
I will now take your place.
He then went to the king's gate.
The people on the road passed on the news, saying:
That great deer king is now coming into the village.
The people of the capital all rushed to watch.
When the king heard this, he thought it was not true.
The gatekeeper reported this to the king, and the king then believed it to be true.
He said:
Why did the king of deer come so suddenly?
The deer said:
There is a pregnant doe about to die, but the fetus has not yet been born. I cannot bear it in my heart, so I dare to offer myself in exchange.
The king heard this and sighed, saying:
You are a human being in the body of a deer, while I am a deer in the body of a human.
Thereupon, he released all the deer and no longer required their lives to be offered. He then made that forest a sanctuary for the deer and called it the Deer Park.
The name Deer Park originated from this.

Two or three li southwest of the monastery, there is a stupa over 300 feet tall, with a broad and imposing base adorned with exquisite treasures. There are no tiered niches on top, but a bowl-shaped cover is placed instead. Although a spire pillar is erected, there are no wheels or bells.

King Åšuddhodana then ordered three members of the royal family and two relatives, saying:

My son SarvÄrthasiddha has left home to study and practice, wandering alone in the mountains and forests, staying alone in the wilderness. Therefore, I order you to follow him and know where he stays.

The five people accepted the order, guarded him in turn, and immediately diligently sought to attain liberation.
They always said to each other:
Is the practice of the Way attained through suffering?
Or is it attained through happiness?
Two of them said:
Happiness is the Way.
Three of them said:

The two groups argued back and forth, but there was no clear resolution.
Then the prince contemplated the ultimate truth, in order to subdue the ascetics who practiced austerities, he limited his intake of sesame and rice to sustain his body.
Those two people saw this and said:
The practices of the prince are not the true Dharma.
The way of the Way is to attain it through joy, but now he is diligently suffering, he is not one of us.
They abandoned him and fled far away, contemplating and attaining realization.
The prince practiced austerities for six years, but did not attain enlightenment. Wishing to verify that ascetic practices were not true, he accepted rice gruel and attained the fruit.
These three people heard this and sighed, saying:
His accomplishments are about to be completed, but now he has retreated.
After six years of ascetic practice, he abandons his efforts in one day!
Then they followed each other in search of the two people. Having seen each other, they sat upright and had lofty discussions, discussing with each other, saying:

In the past, I saw Prince SarvÄrthasiddha leave the royal palace and go to the wilderness, where he discarded his precious garments and put on deerskin, diligently striving with a sincere and resolute mind, seeking profound and wondrous teachings, aiming for the unsurpassed fruit.
Now, he has accepted the milk porridge from a cowherd woman, ruining his path and compromising his resolve. I know this, but there is nothing I can do.
Those two people said:
Why do you see this so late?
He is just a reckless person.

Living in the deep palace, comfortably in a superior position, he is unable to calm his mind and go far into the mountains and forests, abandoning the position of a wheel-turning king to engage in the conduct of a lowly person. How can this be thought of?
It only increases worry and distress!

Going two or three li east of the Shi Lu Forest, I reached a stupa. Beside it, there was a dried-up pond, more than eighty steps in circumference, also called Saving Lives or Heroic Man.
I heard the elders say:

Several hundred years ago, there was a recluse who built a hut and secluded himself by this pond. He extensively studied skills and arts, and thoroughly understood the principles of the spirit, being able to turn tiles and pebbles into treasures and change the forms of humans and animals. However, he was still unable to ride on the wind and clouds and accompany the immortals.
He looked at the maps and ancient records, and further sought immortal techniques.
The method is as follows:
Immortals are the art of longevity.
If one wishes to study it, first determine one's resolve, build an altar, one zhang or more in circumference.
Order a brave man, whose loyalty and valor are well-known, to hold a long sword, stand in the corner of the altar, stop breathing and cease speaking from dusk until dawn;
The seeker of immortality sits in the center of the altar, holds the long sword in hand, recites the divine mantra, focuses the eyes, listens inwardly, and at dawn ascends to become an immortal.

The sharp sword held changes into a precious sword, soars in the void, traverses the sky, becomes the king of the immortals, and with the sword's point and command, all desires are fulfilled, without decline, old age, illness, or death.
This person, having obtained the immortal method, went to search for a brave man, seeking for many years, but never fulfilled his wish.
Later, in the city, he encountered a man who was crying as he went along the road.
The reclusive scholar saw his appearance and was very delighted. He approached and comforted him, asking:
Why are you so sorrowful?
He said:
I am poor and destitute, making a living by hired labor.
My employer sees that I am diligent and trustworthy, and promises a generous reward at the end of five years.
Thus, I endure hardships and forget the difficulties.
In the fifth year, I made a mistake one day, was beaten and humiliated, and received nothing.
With this in mind, I am sorrowful and have no one to care for me.

The recluse invited him to travel together and came to the grass hut. By his magical power, he conjured up a feast. Then, he told him to bathe in the pool and put on new clothes. He also gave him five hundred gold coins, saying:
Use them up and come again to ask for more. Please do not refuse.
From then on, he repeatedly gave him heavy gifts and secretly performed good deeds to move his heart.
The valiant man repeatedly sought to repay his benefactor by offering his life.
The recluse said:
I have been seeking a brave man for many years. Fortunately, I have met you, with extraordinary features that match the description. There is no other reason, I only wish for one night of silence.
The brave man said:
I would not even avoid death, how much less would I refrain from silence?
Then they set up an altar, received the immortal methods, performed the rites according to the instructions, and sat waiting for the sun to set.
After dusk, each performed their duties - the recluse recited the divine incantations, and the brave man held a sharp knife.
It was almost dawn when they suddenly let out a cry.
At that time, fire fell from the sky, with billowing smoke and steam. The recluse quickly led the man into the pool to avoid the danger.
After a while, he asked:

The brave man said:
After receiving the order, at the time of midnight, I became dazed as if in a dream, and strange things arose again.
I saw my former master personally come to comfort and apologize to me. Feeling his deep gratitude, I couldn't bear not to speak to him;
The man became enraged and killed him.
The one who received the intermediate existence body looked back at the corpse with regret, still wishing not to speak for the rest of his life to repay his great kindness.
He then saw himself reborn in a great brahmin family in southern India, and even though he experienced the womb and birth, enduring hardships, he never uttered a word of gratitude.
When he received education, got married, lost his parents, and had a son, he always remembered his past kindness and endured not speaking. His relatives all found it strange.
When he was over sixty-five years old, my wife said to him:
You can speak now!
If you don't speak, I will kill your son.
I then thought that it had been a lifetime since then, and looking at myself, I was old and only had this young son. So I stopped my wife from killing him.
That's why I let out that sound.

The hero was grateful, but was sad that his plan had failed, and died of anger and resentment.

Going east along the Ganges River from here for more than 300 li, I reached the country of Zhanzhu, in the territory of Central India.

The surrounding walls are not wide, but the carvings and decorations are very exquisite. The flowers and ponds reflect each other, and the terraces and pavilions are connected. The monks are solemn and orderly in their conduct.
I heard from the elders of the past:

In the past, in the country of Tukhara north of the Great Snow Mountains, there were monks who enjoyed learning, two or three like-minded friends, who, after finishing their ritual chanting, often said to each other:

Thus, two or three friends, carrying their staffs, traveled together.
Having arrived in India, they stayed in various monasteries, but because they were from the borderlands, no one would take them in.
Exposed to wind and rain outside, and burdened by hunger and thirst inside, their complexions became haggard and their appearances withered.
At that time, the king of this country went out to the suburbs and saw the visiting monks. He found it strange and asked:

The monks replied:

Respectfully following the bequeathed teachings, they soared above worldly dust, leading those with similar interests to observe and pay homage to the sacred sites.
They lamented that due to meager blessings, they were all abandoned by the masses, and Indian monks were disregarded as travelers.
Wishing to return to their homeland, their pilgrimage was not yet complete. Although they were beset by hardships, they were determined to continue.
Upon hearing their account, the king felt even more sorrowful. He built a monastery on this excellent site and wrote in white silk, composing a decree:

Since I am a king, I have received the Buddha's entrustment. All those who have dyed their robes, I shall provide for.

From now on, monks with pierced ears will not be allowed to stay in this monastery.
Because of this incident, it was named accordingly.
Going southeast from Apiduojia Lan for more than 100 li, crossing the Ganges to the south, we reach the town of Mahasala, where the people are all Brahmins who do not follow the Buddha's teachings.
However, when they see a monk, they first inquire about his studies. If they find out he has extensive knowledge, they will then deeply respect him.
To the north of the Ganges, there is a temple dedicated to Narayana.

The images of the gods are carved in stone, the craftsmanship is superb, and the spiritual responses are difficult to fathom.

The TathÄgata, out of compassion for sentient beings who could not die a proper death, used his spiritual powers to guide and transform the ghosts, leading them to pay respect by taking refuge, and observing the precept against killing.

From that time on, those without faith competed to move the stone seat placed by the ghost, trying thousands of times, but none could move it.
The lush forest and clear pond surround the base on the left and right, and people who come to its side cannot help but be afraid.

In the past, after the Tathagata's nirvana, the eight great kings divided the relics. The Brahmin who measured the relics smeared honey inside the bottle and distributed it to the kings. Later, King Asoka opened and took the relic bottle, rebuilt a large stupa, and sometimes on the fast day, the light shines.
